content.description:
The equilibrium for the reaction between <math alttext="open parenthesis, C H 3, close parenthesis, 2, N H" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>(CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow></math>, a weak base, and water is represented by the equation below. The table shows the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of three solutions of <math alttext="open parenthesis, C H 3, close parenthesis, 2, N H aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>(CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>NH(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius " display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
<math alttext="open parenthesis, C H 3, close parenthesis, 2, N H aqueous plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium with open parenthesis, C H 3, close parenthesis, 2, N H 2 with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus O H with a negative 1 charge aqueous. K sub b equals 5.4 times 10 to the negative 4 power at 25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>NH(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>(CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="2.0em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>5.4</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>at</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="the molar concentration of open parenthesis, C H 3, close parenthesis, 2, N H" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><mtext>(</mtext><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="p H at 25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH at</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> 0.050 11.69 0.10 11.85 0.20 12.01
content.question: Which of the following equations can be used to correctly calculate the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of a solution at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that is <math alttext="0.100 molar open parenthesis, C H 3, close parenthesis, 2, N H aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>(</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>NH(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.100 molar open parenthesis, C H 3, close parenthesis, 2, N H 2 C l aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cl(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="p H equals the negative log of the fraction with numerator, 1 times 1.0 times 10 to the negative 14 power, and denominator, 5.4 times 10 to the negative 4 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mtext>log</mtext></mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>5.4</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="p H equals the negative log of the fraction with numerator, 5.4 times 10 to the negative 4 power, and denominator, 1.0 times 10 to the negative 14 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mtext>log</mtext></mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>5.4</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="p H equals 14.00 plus the negative log of 5.4 times 10 to the negative 4 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>14.00</mn><mo>+</mo><mtext>(</mtext><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtext>log</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace></mrow><mn>5.4</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="p H equals the negative log of 5.4 times 10 to the negative 4 power, plus the log of the fraction 0.100 over 0.100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext>(</mtext><mrow><mo>−</mo><mtext>log</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace></mrow><mn>5.4</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>log(</mtext><mfrac><mrow><mn>0.100</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>0.100</mn></mrow></mfrac><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="p H equals the negative log of the fraction with numerator, 1 times 1.0 times 10 to the negative 14 power, and denominator, 5.4 times 10 to the negative 4 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mtext>log</mtext></mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>5.4</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 5.F: Calculate, estimate, or predict an unknown quantity from known quantities by selecting and following a logical computational pathway and attending to precision (e.g., performing dimensional analysis and attending to significant figures).
